text: OF TACITUS. 225 gones, of commotions in favour of Vitel- lius, went over to the standard of Fabius Valens. Their arrogance, from that time, knew no bounds. They paraded the camp, in every quarter, and in the tents of the legions, making it their boast," that by" them the fourteenth legion had been" overawed; by them Italy was wrested" out of the hands of Nero; and upon" their swords the issue of the war de-" pended." The Roman soldiers heard these speeches with indignation; disputes and quarrels filled the camp, and disci- pline was at an end. Valens saw his au- thority lessened, and knew too well, that, from clamour to actual mutiny the transi- tion is short and sudden. XXVIII. In this posture of affairs, Va- lens received advice that the Tungrians and Treverians had met with a defeat, and that Otho's fleet was hovering on the coast of Narbon Gaul.
